stream_context.summary: Kaze worked live on the new Western-themed course for "Return to Yoshi’s Island," modelling a low-poly, moving train, reviewing building placements, and describing planned gameplay (sheriff’s office, bank robbery aftermath, tumbleweed store, five-Goomba gang showdown). He also discussed engine optimisations and his design philosophy.

development_findings.summary: The level will feature a fully explorable cowboy town with specific buildings: sheriff’s office (holds 3 captured criminals), hat shop, random houses, ‘Big Iron’ gun store, hotel, tumbleweed shop (player can buy a tumbleweed), chain-chomp yard, bank robbed before Mario arrives, Unagi-oil salesman, and a saloon.
development_findings.quote: I'll give you a rundown of the buildings… this will be the sheriff's office… next up here we have the cowboy store… this right here is gonna be the bank—there is a bank robbery in this level but you kind of just come in post after the robbery.

development_findings.summary: Enemy concept: a five-Goomba outlaw gang, plus a Snufit and a Shy Guy as cowboy enemies. A standoff scene is planned.
development_findings.quote: There’s gonna be a goomba or five goombas rather—they are a gang… We definitely want a standoff, but instead of a normal standoff actually what we'll have is a standoff of the five Goombas.

development_findings.summary: Kaze designed a low-poly train inspired by Mario Kart 64’s Calamari Desert and MK7 versions, keeping the red/yellow ‘64’ logo, adding 3-D wheels, and sizing it to Mario. The train will run every ~10 seconds on a circular track once collision is baked.
development_findings.quote: I think I want just the choo-choo train and then you can just jump on it… train passes every 10 seconds.

development_findings.summary: Technical optimisation: the game detects if it’s running on emulator; on emulator it enables unlimited draw distance and 60 FPS default.
development_findings.quote: I'm making it so that on emulator drawing distances are unlimited for example and it defaults to 60 fps instead of 30.

development_findings.summary: Rendering efficiency: coins (and other billboards) are now drawn once in screen space instead of per-object matrices, saving ~256 bytes per coin and reducing commands.
development_findings.quote: Drawing them in screen space once is a lot faster—you save like almost 256 bytes of data per coin.

development_findings.summary: Current performance: unfinished level already runs 40–50 FPS on real hardware before any optimisation.
development_findings.quote: I tested this level… This level ran pretty stable, 40 to 50 fps. And we haven't even optimized it yet.

development_findings.summary: Visual style decision: exclude Native-American stereotypes and instead ‘over-cowboy’ the theme as a parody of Western tropes.
development_findings.quote: We want to just a hundred percent cowboy this… but we won't portray Native American people.

development_findings.summary: Influences cited: Westworld TV series for mood; Calamari Desert assets; Mario Party Western Land music.
Collision baking for the track must wait until the town layout is final; train programming is postponed until then.
development_findings.quote: We can't program the train yet, because we need the collision baked for that. And to bake the collision, we need to finish the level.

context_findings.summary: Kaze prefers intrinsic over extrinsic game motivation and criticises Tears of the Kingdom and Pokémon for ‘collect-athon’ design.
context_findings.quote: Everywhere you go there's some amount of extrinsic motivation… it just feels like I'm ant collecting sugar and not really playing a game.

context_findings.summary: He is monitoring YouTube metrics and is frustrated that a favorite video has high CTR and retention yet low views, suspecting algorithm mismatch.
context_findings.quote: 11% click-through rate? That's insane… It's just not being shown to anyone.

context_findings.summary: Personal interests: currently only watching cowboy TV shows while working to stay in theme; discusses weight-lifting habits and gives chat fitness advice.
context_findings.quote: My dedication to the cowboy theme is still big, I started only watching cowboy TV shows while working on this. I am literally watching Westworld right now.

biobak.summary: Pointed out misplaced vertices on decorative balls and will redo the 64 logo texture for the train.
biobak.quote: Good point Biobak, they were half as up down as they need to be… Biobak says do not worry, he will make it better later.

zeina.summary: Brief on-stream chat about Christmas gifts; no project details shared.

key_stories.title: Building the Train
key_stories.summary: Chat supplied a Mario Kart 7 train rip; Kaze decided to combine textures from it with his own low-poly model, added 3-D wheels, resized it and tested in-game.
key_stories.challenge: Needed a Western train that matched the hack’s art style without importing a high-poly model.
key_stories.process: Reviewed MK64 and MK7 references, extracted textures, modelled a 182-triangle engine in Blender, iteratively adjusted size and wheels, and tested on hardware.
key_stories.outcome: Final engine model approved; movement coding deferred until track collision is baked.
key_stories.key_quote: I think the train shape is good so far… this is a beautiful train.
